ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual lectures and weekly section with TA.
We also had virtual discussion sections
In-person lecture and virtual discussion section.
Virtual weekly discussion sections
In-person lecture + virtual discussion section.
In person lectures, recorded and made available on canvas. Discussion sessions on Zoom.
In-person lecture plus one online discussion section a week.
Discussion section (virtual)
discussion sections were online.
Zoom
Virtual sections.
online live section as well
Recorded lecture, virtual discussion section, and live virtual lecture.
Virtual discussion section
backup live virtual lecture
In person lectures and virtual discussion sections.
Live virtual discussion section
In person lecture that is recorded, with a weekly discussion section
live virtual lectures
I (and I think most other students) never went to the in-person lectures, instead watching the recordings online.
Contained in- person lectures, virtual discussion formats as well as recorded lectures.
recorded lectures and virtual discussion sections
in-person lecture and virtual discussion section
At times when I could not attend the in-person lecture, I watched the recorded session online.
The course was a combination of in-person lectures (which were also recorded and uploaded for those who were unable to be present physically) and virtual discussion sections.
Lectures also recorded, complemented by weekly virtual discussion sections.
This course combined an in person lecture with virtual discussion sections.
in person lecture

in-person lecture 
virtual discussion sections
Weekly virtual discussion sections
Weekly discussion sections.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Not much tbh other than some interesting discussions that I got into thanks to it.
You got to read about many influential writers and philosophers throughout history.
I learned a lot about the philosophy of education.
I think this course helped me to get introduced to essential themes such as character, community, responsibility and education in different eras and different cultures.
I learned about the views of various philosophers about the role of education for an individual and society.

If this course is done diligently, it provides an introduction to a few seminal texts across eras, covering texts from Aristotle to Virginia Woolf and a good exposure to a few different kinds of moral questions that one might encounter in college life. However, to most international students this year, this pass/fail course was an anti-deportation class, satisfying our in-person requirement for the semester, so not many were devoted to the course content.
Insights that I developed in this course would pro
The value of a college education - interesting readings on education and character-building.
I learned a little bit about Yale's history and about the purpose of education in general. I practiced reading more challenging texts.
A more well-rounded critical view on higher education.
A lot of reading
Insight into the history of education and educational philosophy

This course was thought-provoking in many correct ways. It made a great case for the importance of a liberal arts education, made me reconsider what I will be doing with my college years, and served as another reminder of Yale's intimate relation with the Great Books and the canon.
I was introduced to various different ideas and concepts philosophers and instrumental authors of the liberal arts thought as the fundamentals of a college education.
A broad survey of philosophical thought regarding education and its value.
I learned to think about the character required for participation in college life, and was introduced to quite a few authors I didn't know of before.
Got to read a wide range of books that has developed my opinions, and the weekly discussion section were good seminar experience.
I developed my writing skills, especially for writing reflections.
It made me think more about the value of education.
Knowledge of several prominent philosophers' views on education.
I learnt more about the different purposes of education, and how students can benefit from a college education. We had interesting discussions and I heard from lots of different perspectives.

I believe that this course strengthened my ability to read primary sources analytically. Also, I gained some interesting knowledge about how great thinkers approached the concept of education in their historical time frames.
Read texts from well-known thinkers and had interesting conversations regarding the purposes of college education, and its relation to qualities such as character and community.
I was able to deepen my understanding of the nuanced facets and impacts of a college education, as well as develop skills such as communication and critical thinking.
The true meanings of Character and how to grow in a community.

I developed a novel appreciation for university education as a concept.

I also discovered fascinating texts I had never encountered before.

Despite the class for the most part consisting of international students, from the texts, lectures, and discussions, I feel that I have developed a novel understanding of college and the educational system in the United States, but also American culture more broadly.
I learned about different iconic philosophers and their points of view on college education.
The aspects which make up a college education
I gained better reading and discussion skills. Reading old classic texts.
I learnt to look at extracts from historical pieces and make comparisons about how certain aspects of life compared to nowadays.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The course's readings are pretty interesting, and both the TAs and Dr. Lewis showed a genuine interest in the course material. Additionally, the writing assignments were geared toward helping students reflect on what they learned. I most loved the final 5 page paper because I got to reflec t on my first semester at Yale and include texts I had read in the class. 

The class could be improved if the TA sections were better prepared for discussion and if the class content was revised just a little. I think most students take the class because they hoped to read influential writers and were much less interested in the purpose of college education.
Everything in this course worked very well for me.

The strength of this class is a geographically and temporarily diverse selection of texts. The weakness of the class might be that lectures rarely offered new material and mostly reiterated what we have already read for the class.

Strengths: Its pass/fail and theres hardly any work assigned (three one-page papers through the semester and a final five-page reflection), making for the perfect fifth/sixth course.
Weaknesses: The lectures can get a little dull in their content, especially for some of the texts that you dont vibe with. Also, the discussion sections do get somewhat awkward when no one contributes.

The strengths of this course would have the ability to attend either an in-person or virtual lecture. Along with this, there was a ton of flexibility for each student in terms of discussion sections and writing essays. When writing the essays assigned to us during the course, it was fun since the questions asked and topics brought about like cancel culture were relatable. Those essays, especially the last essay, were nice for reflection and helped make a person feel better, especially during the 1st semester of Yale. I wouldn't change anything other than having everything in-person.

Strengths - low workload, interesting reading materials and discussions and pertinent questions + a global outlook. 
Weaknesses - discussion session
Every lecture is very well structured and entertaining. We received all material and instructions to complete assignments and be prepared for lectures.
Slightly more variety in the form of assignments would make the class even more engaging
The prof is great.
It could focus more on class discussions.

Strengths: Readings, Discussion Sections
Weaknesses: Lecture Duration + The lecture could have been more interactive

The content is very interesting, and the level of work assigned is appropriate. I do hope that it could be more provocative and combative! The class wasn't at all navel-gazing as is a lot of talk about education within educational institutions, and the most interesting parts of the class was when professor Lewis was teasing at some challenge to widely-held beliefs and convictions of Yale students. Unfortunately, we never really got to fight it out!
This was a good course to learn about a variety of different writings and readings. It was especially nice since this course was offered for the fall semester.

I thought the discussion sections were where I was most engaged. I enjoyed them and they allowed me to flesh out my understanding better. The course material was solid. Perhaps encouraging others to engage more during discussion sections would be the most useful improvement.

The inperson lecture was very interesting and well done. I think there were too many readings assigned of too long  a length to really read through properly before a lecture. The discussion section was too disorganized to be really interesting.
It's a good course, that covers some interesting topics.

Strength: Weekly discussions are interesting, especially with real world applications

Weakness: Some of the readings can be a bit heavy
The strength is that we get to extract famous texts and apply them to the value of education.
Book selection very good. Discussions were often held back by all the kids who did not read.

I thought this was a great course! As it was a half credit class, I felt some of the readings were quite long and confusing. I enjoyed the lecture and the professor was engaging. The discussion sections were also beneficial as we could learn from other students.

In my opinion, the primary sources we got to read were quite interesting. Also, I liked how Professor Lewis tried to engage students in live lectures. One weakness, in my opinion, was that perhaps many students did not feel motivated enough to engage during the discussion sections for one reason or the other.

This was a great class! The readings were really rewarding and not particularly long. Professor Lewis is a great lecturer and made the course interactive with in-class discussions. It was honestly the highlight of my week since the class was in person. The assignments were really easy and fun to write.

Overall, the course was fantastic! The content was very interesting and the discussions were engaging. Professor Lewis is an incredible professor who is passionate, eloquent and evidently highly-knowledgeable about the course content. The mixed structure of the class was effective in maximizing learning, and the workload was good. What could be improved is the fact that the course is only 0.5 credits, and is Pass/Fail; I wish the course could have been at least 1 credit and could have provided some grade or fulfilled a distributional requirement, such as for the Humanities.
This course was an in person lecture, which connected weekly readings to powerpoint content. The course did a great job of condensing difficult philosophical material into easily understood themes.
required a lot of long challenging readings which made it difficult to remain engaged

strengths: the professor is really good
weaknesses: the material was not super interesting (maybe because it was not in my area of interest)

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual discussion sections were very helpful since there was less opportunity to form small groups in the in-person lectures, however in each lecture we had at least one group discussion with the students we were sitting close with so that was also a positive experience.
The class successfully adapted to the virtual setting
The in-person lectures were a lot of fun to attend, and definitely the best part of the course.

Discussion sessions with TA could be imporved. 
Production, recording of live lectures were spot-on, in-person lectures were well organized and socially distanced.

As one of the few in-person lectures, coming to the lecture hall and the seating was very well organized to ensure everyone's safety. There was a large variety of times for when to have the discussion section, which is friendly towards any schedule.
The in-person aspect was conducted soundly. Social distancing and communication was handled very well.
I think the course was run well.
Offering the recorded lecture afterwards

That this class was held successfully without outbreak shows that we can have in-person learning in die coronazeit! Zoom sections aren't much fun, but because of the zoom, not because of the section -- the actual discussions were great.
This course was great.
While I was quarantined, I sincerely appreciated the Live Stream of the course. Furthermore, breakout rooms during Zoom to gather our thoughts were a useful discussion tool.
Nothing much really, the Canvas page was terribly laid out and the virtual weekly sessions were very disorganized.  The in person lecture was the best part.
During our in-person lectures, lots of measures were taken to protect us.
This was a hybrid class, although many people didn't incline to attend the in person lecture because they can watch the recordings online.
They all succeeded, and they were very fexible.
All practices were great, I wouldn't change anything.
In my opinion, the course practices were very convenient. I like how the course provided both in-person attendance opportunity as well as recorded sessions for those students who missed a lecture.

It was helpful that Professor Lewis provided a live in-person option for the lectures, but also had alternatives available, such as recorded versions of the lecture. Honestly, everything was well-designed.
The safety precautions taken at in-person lectures were very reassuring and effective.

The course succeeded in terms of the in person lectures, where everyone was properly spaced out with masks on. The only improvement I would make to the course is adding more structure to weekly discussion sections, as the topic of conversation oftentimes strayed away from the lesson goals.
all covid safety measures were implemented to their best during the in-person lectures
Socially-distanced in-person lectures where everyone wears a mask helped keep the lectures safe.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this class to another student with a tough workload that needs .5 more credits. The pass fail class is really a choose your own adventure. If you want to really engage with the content and learn a lot about influential writers, this class is a perfect space to do so without worrying too much about grades. I enjoyed my experience thoroughly.
Perfect for international students.

I would recommend this course if one wants to get an introduction to how to do readings and how to discuss them as well as if they are interested in the approach to education in different eras/ views.

If you're interested in a light introduction to various philosophical perspectives on the purposes of education, yes, you may find this class interesting. If you don't have a special interest in this area or have had studied philosophy before, I would not recommend taking this class

In this semester, most enrolled students were internationals trying to satisfying their visa requirements. However, if youre interested in exploring some interesting and thought-provoking texts in a low stress environment, this course might be for you.

if you need an easy f-1 in-person class to subvert visa requirements - YES
If you have a niche interest in the value of college education (as a college student) - SURE
if you want to be challenged or constantly engaged - NO

I would recommend this course as the content was very enlightening. Even though we looked at works of authors long deceased, the purpose was still relevant and it gave me a new perspective on college education.
Absolutely - it was well structured and a great complement to a diverse courseload
Yes - us international first years needed an in-person course for our visas. For non-internationals, it's a free 1/2 credit with practically no work.

Yes! You've made it to Yale. You probably have a lot of ideas about what you'll do later in your life, what you want to learn, what type of person you are, what type of place Yale is, which is exactly why you should take this class to consider the opposite of all those beliefs.
Yes, if you're interested in a survey philosophy course.
I would as it was rather interesting and introduced me to people I wouldn't have read otherwise.
Yes.
Yes, if you need 0.5 pass/fail credit
Yes, the discussions are fun.
Yes. Amount we learned per unit time was very high. Not stressful at all but very interesting and instructive.
Yes, it allows you to think about how college education is applied in day-to-day living.
Yes, I enjoyed the class.

I would recommend this course to someone who is interested in the concept of education and how it evolved over time. Since the workload is quite light, I believe that this course is perfect for someone who is looking to engage with the given material freely. I also find Professor Lewis's lectures to be quite interesting.
Yes! It's a fun and easy class.

I would recommend this course to another student. The course allowed me to internally explore my own motivations and goals in my college education. It was helpful to take this course as a first year student, as I believe it will help me make the most of my college experience.

I personally would not take this course if it wasn't a visa requirement. I think that Prof. Lewis is amazing and super smart and has amazing stories to tell, but most of the course is just boring. We learnt about people who set the stage of how society functions today which is super important, but was just not engaging at all. I liked that I had the chance to meet a lot of other international students, but I could not keep my attending during the class even if I tried super hard.
